title-group.article-title: Cerebral Abscess Complicating Proteus mirabilis Meningitis in a Newborn Infant

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Pediatrics, UCLA Medical Center, Los Angeles, CA, USA
2Division of Pediatric Infectious Diseases, Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, Los Angeles, CA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Deborah Lehman, MD, Division of Pediatric Infectious Diseases, 8700 Beverly Boulevard, Room 4221, Los Angeles, CA 90048 Email: debbie.lehman@cshs.org

abstract.p: Neonatal bacterial meningitis is associated with high morbidity and mortality, especially when complicated by intracranial abscesses. The authors report the case of an 11-day-old female with Proteus mirabilis meningitis complicated by an asymptomatic brain abscess. With this report, the authors illustrate the importance of surveillance neuroradiologic imaging in patients with Proteus meningitis.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: An 11-day-old female was admitted to the hospital for increasing irritability since the previous evening and a fever of 101.2°F and poor feeding on the morning of admission.

The patient was born at 40-weeks gestation by normal spontaneous vaginal delivery. Prenatal labs were all normal, the pregnancy was uncomplicated, and mother denied any infections during the pregnancy. Labor and delivery were complicated by possible prolonged rupture of membranes 36 hours prior to delivery. Of note, there was no maternal temperature, maternal tachycardia, or fetal tachycardia; and no intrapartum antibiotics were given.

On presentation to the hospital, her temperature was 102.8°F, with blood pressure of 110/53 mmHg, heart rate of 165 beats per minute, and respiratory rate of 60 breaths per minute. On physical exam, she was irritable but consolable and had dry mucous membranes. Capillary refill time was delayed at 5 seconds. Her anterior fontanelle was soft and nonbulging, and she was moving her neck in all directions. Her lungs were clear to auscultation, heart tones were normal, and she did not have a murmur. There were no spinal defects noted, including sacral dimples or tufts of hair.

Laboratory data on admission showed a white blood cell count of 16 400 cell/μL with 74% polymorphonuclear neutrophils, 2% band neutrophils, 13% lymphocytes, and 11% monocytes. The hemoglobin was 18.3 g/dL, and platelet count was 316 000 cell/μL. Cerebrospinal fluid studies obtained 18 hours after initiation of antibiotics showed a WBC count of 5300 cell/μL, with 84% polymorphonuclear neutrophils, 5% lymphocytes, and 10% monocytes/macrophages and a red blood cell count of 1250 cell/μL. The cerebrospinal fluid had glucose of 37 mg/dL and protein of 122 mg/dL. Gram stain of the cerebrospinal fluid showed no bacteria. At 24 hours, the blood culture grew pan-sensitive Proteus mirabilis, and the cerebrospinal fluid culture grew 1 colony of the same organism. A urinalysis was normal, and urine culture was sterile.

Upon admission, patient was immediately started on ampicillin and gentamicin at meningitic dosing. She continued to have fevers up to 102°F 24 hours after initiation of antibiotics. At that time, the gentamicin was changed to meningitic dosing of cefotaxime, and she became afebrile by 48 hours following initiation of antibiotics.

A repeat blood culture was drawn on hospital day 3 and was negative. Repeat cerebrospinal fluid examination on hospital day 5 showed a decrease in the white blood cell count to 101 cell/μL, with 30% polymorphonuclear neutrophils, 34% lymphocytes, and 34% monocytes/macrophages and a red blood cell count of 33 cell/μL. The cerebrospinal fluid had glucose of 39 mg/dL and protein of 134 mg/dL. This cerebrospinal fluid culture was negative. On hospital day 7, computed tomography of the brain with iodinated intravenous contrast was done and revealed a left frontal centrum semiovale 6.5-mm cavitary lesion with surrounding edema and diffuse cerebritis. A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain with intravenous gadolinium done the following day showed an area of lucency approximately 1 cm in diameter in the mid left frontal convexity white matter without evidence for contrast enhancement around it. T2 weighted views showed white matter edema around this area. Repeat magnetic resonance imaging of the brain with and without intravenous gadolinium contrast on hospital day 19 showed better definition of the left frontal lobe abscess without change in size. The patient remained on double antibiotic coverage with cefotaxime and gentamicin for 14 days and finished a total treatment course of 6 weeks on cefotaxime. A final MRI done on hospital day 40 showed almost complete resolution of the left frontal lesion

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Bacterial meningitis in the neonatal period is associated with much morbidity and mortality. It is usually secondary to bacteremia and can be complicated by intracranial abscess formation in up to 13% of cases,1 particularly in cases of meningitis due to Citrobacter sp.2 Development of such a complication may lead to a worsened prognosis for patients, putting them at increased risk of neurologic sequelae, developmental delay, audiologic and visual impairment, or even death.3

Our case of late-onset neonatal meningitis was the result of Proteus mirabilis septicemia in an infant with one possible risk factor, prolonged rupture of membranes. Proteus mirabilis is a non-lactose fermenting gram-negative bacillus that characteristically swarms on the surface of moist agar media. The organism produces hydrogen sulfide and liquefies gelatin.2 There are several species of Proteus, but Proteus mirabilis and Proteus vulgaris account for the vast majority of clinical isolates. Proteus spp. are a common cause of urinary tract infections; however, osteomyelitis, mastoiditis, and wound infections have been also been reported.2 It has been recognized to be the causative organism in approximately 4% of neonatal gram-negative meningitis4 and has been a documented cause of meningitis as early as 1897,5 with reports of subsequent brain abscess formation and fatality (Table 1).

caption.p: Reports of Proteus Meningitis Complicated by Cerebral Abscess

tr.td: Premature, LBW, omphalitis, peritonitis, cystic kidney
4 with maternal Proteus UTI, 13 had bacteremia
Bacteremia, probable premature rupture of membranes

fn.p: Abbreviations: LBW, low birth weight; —, data not available; UTI, urinary tract infection.
a Twenty-seven of 30 observed brain abscesses were due to Proteus mirabilis.

sec.p: While most reported cases of brain abscess resulting from Proteus meningitis occurred in patients who displayed neurologic abnormalities, which led to further neuroradiologic investigation,5-7,9 our patient was found to have an asymptomatic intracranial abscess. Because the patient did not have any focal neurologic signs, we did not suspect any intracranial complications. Because Proteus is a less common cause of neonatal meningitis, we decided to perform a surveillance image that surprisingly showed an intracranial abscess. Interestingly, our patient had an abscess present in the setting of an improved cerebral spinal fluid profile, which is in contrast to a previous observation that patients with abscesses had continued pleocytosis despite adequate antibiotic treatment.9 Given this finding, an improving cerebrospinal fluid profile should not necessarily provide clinical reassurance or rule out the possibility of a developing intracranial abscess.

It is well described that Citrobacter meningitis can be associated with intracranial abscesses, occurring in up to 80% of cases.12 With this notion, other gram-negative meningitis may not be evaluated by neuroradiologic imaging in the absence of neurologic symptoms. As shown in Table 1, there have been multiple fatal cases of neonatal Proteus meningitis complicated by intracranial abscess. It should be recognized that Proteus infections also put patients at risk for the development of intracranial abscess formation, even in the absence of focal neurologic symptoms and in those patients with improving cerebral spinal fluid profile. Two studies have noted the recurrence of Proteus meningitis after a sufficient course of appropriate antibiotic treatment, suggesting these cases may have also had an occult intracranial abscess, discovered upon the relapse.8,11 In light of our observation and the aforementioned data, we feel it prudent to perform neuroradiologic imaging in all cases of Proteus meningitis, even in the absence of neurologic findings and even in the setting of improved cerebral spinal fluid profile.

fn.p: Both authors contributed equally to this submission. DL considered the case for manuscript preparation and submission. HP drafted the original manuscript, and both DL and HP revised the article and approved this final version for publishing consideration.
